See the stories of five trans Mississippians.
I TOO AM MISSISSIPPI STORYTELLING PROJECT

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

Mississippi is home to 15,000 transgender and gender non-conforming individuals. Yet, many of our policymakers say they have never met a trans person, and policies and hateful rhetoric continue to perpetuate discrimination.

The I Too Am Mississippi Storytelling Project, part of our Transgender Education and Advocacy Program, is aimed at elevating the voices, faces, and lives of Mississippi’s transgender citizens. By challenging restrictive narratives about who belongs and who gets to fully participate in society, we can advance justice and dismantle the hatred of difference.

We invite you to meet Alicia, Fiona, Shaun, Stephenie, and Jensen at one of our storytelling events. We will showcase their short films, a pop-up exhibit, and a catalog of photos. During each event, there will also be an opportunity to dialogue with the participants. We hope you can join us in Tupelo, Hattiesburg, or Gulfport for one of our I Too Am Mississippi Storytelling project events:

Tupelo
Saturday, October 6, 6:30 p.m.
Elvis Presley Birthplace Center
306 Elvis Presley Dr.
Tupelo, MS 38801
Sign Up »

Hattiesburg
Wednesday, October 10, 6 p.m.
Southern Prohibition Brewery
301 Mobile St.
Hattiesburg, MS 39401
Sign Up »

Gulfport
Friday, October 19, 7 p.m.
Sipps Bar
2218 25th Ave.
Gulfport, MS 39501
Sign Up »

After tomorrow’s premiere, you can watch their personal stories on our website. Then, tell us how "You Too Are Mississippi" by uploading your own video on the We Are All Mississippi Facebook page or emailing it to teapms@aclu-ms.org.

It is our hope that these stories help build a bridge between the sociological perceptions and the individually lived realities of trans Mississippians.

In unity,

Jennifer Riley-Collins
Executive Director, ACLU of Mississippi
